_prev_prog_3.Description: Preferred Freezer Services prevention program is implemented to operate and maintain the process safely according to industry standards adopted by the International Insitute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) and following recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices to meet the local, state and federal regulatory requirements.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Preferred Freezer Services of Norton

Executive Summary



In response to Local Emergency Management Agencies, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), this Risk Management Plan has been developed for Preferred Freezer Services of Norton. The prevention program has been prepared for ensuring: 



?    the protection of public health, the environment, and Preferred Freezer Services of Norton employees by ensuring safe operation and maintenance practices that follow industry standards and meet recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices



?    proper emergency response and mitigation procedures when handling regulated substances.



?    Preferred Freezer Services of Norton and local government agencies are together in their communication and coordination efforts to improve safety while handling regulated substances.



The content of the risk management program is implemented in conjunction with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), process safety program PSM 1910.119 and addresses Preferred Freezer Services of Norton administrative and operational programs to prevent accidents related to regulated substances and to reduce potential risks. The chemical Anhydrous Ammonia is used to provide refrigeration for warehouse cold/freezer storage, and dock operations. Ammonia is dangerous in high concentration, but has a self alarming odor at very low concentrations making it easy to identify when a leak is small. Anhydrous ammonia is a natural refrigerant that's environmentally friendly and does not cause harm to the ozone layer.



PROCESS DESCRIPTION

Preferred Freezer Services of Norton operates an industrial refrigeration system that contains Anhydrous Ammonia. The refrigeration system is located in the main building.



The refrigeration cycle is a closed-loop process. The refrigeration cycle utilizes fluid temperature, pressure, and latent heat of vaporization to remove heat from a desired area, and then to discard that heat, through conde

nsation, to an area where it is of no consequence.

Release Prevention Program Elements. 



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Every section of the PSM program must allow for employee participation in its development and implementation. The plan allowing for this participation must be documented. Employees and their representatives must have access to all information required to be developed for the Process Safety Management program without regard to possible trade secret status of such information.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

Complete and accurate written information concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment is essential to an effective PSM program and to other aspects such as the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA). The information to be compiled about the chemicals needs to be comprehensive enough for an accurate assessment of the fire and explosion characteristics, reactivity hazards, the health and safety hazards to workers, and the corrosion effects on process equipment as well as monitoring and safety related equipment. Safety Data Sheet (SDS) information can provide a portion of the required data but other information will be required.



Process technology information is also required. This includes information on the amount of hazardous material stored and used at the facility as well as operating limits for the process. Diagrams of the system and information on all of the equipment utilized in the system are required. Piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) are included in the Process Safety Information.



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is the basis for many of the decisions and procedures associated with an effective PSM program. It is a systematic effort to determine the potential hazards associated with the process and to evaluate mitigation alternatives including equipment modifications, procedural modifications, training, and administrative controls. An effective PHA considers and analyzes the potenti

al consequences associated with a release of the hazardous materials including fires, explosions, and exposure of people to toxic materials. It focuses on equipment, instrumentation, utilities, human actions, and external events.



To ensure that both operator safety as well as off-site safety is addressed, "What-If/Checklist" analysis is conducted during the PHA session. Siting issues and Human factors to assess such as lighting, accessibility, and overall working conditions were incorporated in the analysis. 



OPERATING PROCEDURES

Operating procedures describe operating conditions to be maintained, and safety and health precautions to be utilized in operation of the process containing regulated substances. The procedures need to be technically accurate and will result in safe operation of the facility. In addition, they need to be understandable to the employees and/or contractors. The procedures are updated as changes are made to the facility or to the operating limits of the system. The employer annually certifies that the operating procedures are current and accurate.



All phases of system operation must be covered by written procedures. Specifically, procedures must be available for:



?    Initial Startup

?    Normal Operations

?    Temporary Operations

?    Emergency Shut Down

?    Emergency Operations

?    Normal Shutdown

?    Start Up Following an Emergency Shut Down or turn around following maintenance.



The procedures contain process operation limits and provide information of the consequences of deviation from these limits and the steps required to correct any deviations. Safety and health measures described in the SDS are referenced to warn employees of potential risks and protective action that should be taken.



EMPLOYEE TRAINING

All employees, including maintenance and contractor employees involved with regulated substances (i.e. Anhydrous Ammonia), need to fully understand the health and safety hazards associated with the chemical with which they are w

orking. This will allow them to better protect themselves, fellow employees, and the neighboring communities. In addition to the normal awareness training, which informs personnel of the hazards of the chemical and the safety precautions to use, training in operating procedures and safe work practices, emergency response, and other required management controls are required at the Preferred Freezer Services of Norton facility.



CONTRACTOR SAFETY

Any use of outside contractors who work in and around the refrigeration system requires that these contractors have accomplished the training, utilize proficient personnel, and have been informed of the necessary health and safety aspects of working in the area. The goal is to assure that contractor employees perform work in a safe manner and do not endanger themselves, other employees, or the facility. 



PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW

For a new design or the addition of significant changes to the process, a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) must be employed to determine that the changes are not themselves deficient or that the addition of the new portions of the system will adversely affect the original system. Management procedures are developed to ensure that a satisfactory hazard analysis has been completed before the system is started.



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

A formal maintenance program is in place for all systems using regulated substances (i.e. Anhydrous Ammonia). This program will consist of routine (scheduled) inspection, testing, overhaul, and replacement as needed. Equipment is categorized and ranked with respect to the maintenance involved. This maintenance and inspection information includes all equipment such as storage vessels, compressors, condensers, evaporators, process piping relief and vent systems, fire protection system components, emergency shutdown systems, and alarms. Each component must be placed into a category that indicates how maintenance and inspection will be performed on that class of compon

ents.



?    Faulty or Unsafe Equipment Report

?    Compressor Operating Log Sheet

?    Daily Inspection Checklist

?    Weekly Inspection Checklist

?    Monthly Inspection Checklist

?    Quarterly Inspection Checklist

?    Semi-Annual Inspection Checklist

?    Annual Inspection Checklist

?    Five-Year Inspection



HOT WORK PERMIT

A management control program is employed that recognizes that extra care is required for non-routine work practices that requires following a permitting process. This program will advise the personnel that significant potential hazards exist and that extra care should be taken in certain circumstances. This will ensure that employees, contractors, and company property are protected against fire, explosion, and other dangers resulting from hot work.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

Other than "replacement in kind," any change to the system is documented. In particular, the change of any equipment, control system, or procedure must be evaluated to determine that it will not have an adverse effect on the safety aspects of the system. In addition, procedures must be revised to reflect the changes in the system.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

Incident investigation is the process of identifying the underlying causes of incidents and implementing steps to prevent similar events from occurring. It is required that employees will recognize and investigate events that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a hazardous chemical release. Employers must develop in-house capabilities to investigate incidents that occur in their facilities. A team must be assembled by this facility and trained to collect and document information related to any incident. Usually a multi-disciplinary team is better able to gather the facts and evaluate "what happened and why." All employees with information should be interviewed and other facts should be gathered to develop a complete picture of the facts concerning the incident. Recommendations are then developed for changes in equipment,

procedures, or safety systems to prevent recurrence of the event.



EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE

Emergency planning is in place in case there is a release of refrigerant (or other emergency such as fire or earthquake). A formal plan on how to handle an emergency situation and also a plan to educate employees as to what they should do is implemented. This is detailed and includes procedures for notifying local authorities and following up with written accident reports, should the release meet or exceed the reportable quantity (100 pounds of anhydrous ammonia). Many local site factors will be included in the emergency action and fire prevention plan. Preferred Freezer Services of Norton has policy of addressing all leaks no matter how small to determine the proper response. Preferred Freezer Services of Norton will assist to and mitigate all leaks within the limits of training and with the proper use of PPE.



COMPLIANCE AUDIT

An effective audit program is required to determine that facility personnel and contractors are following the procedures and intents of the overall PSM requirements. Periodic reviews of all areas of the management programs are required to verify compliance. OSHA has published compliance guidelines for their compliance personnel. These guidelines make a good basis for developing an internal audit program. Corrective actions related to the audit will need to be documented and kept on record to show how the audit is improving the overall performance of the risk management programs in place.



TRADE SECRETS

Employees have access to all information necessary (without regard to possible trade secret status of such information) Information available to those persons responsible for:

?    Compiling the process safety information.

?    Assisting in the development of the process hazard analysis.

?    Responsible for developing the operating procedures.

?    Involved in incident investigations, emergency planning and response, and compliance audits.

Th

ere are no trade secret processes, information, or designs related to this refrigeration system.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

There has been one accident involving an ammonia leak that resulted in evacuations at the Preferred Freezers Norton facility and off site residences. 



PLANS FOR FUTURE IMPROVEMENTS

It is the intent of Preferred Freezers Norton facility to continue compliance with OSHA and EPA regulations for the safety and well being of the employees and the local community. 

Enigineered controls added into the recently upgraded process assure that recoognized and generally accepted good engineering practices are in place that follow industry standards.
